title: The Journey From No Laptop to a $3B Company
description: Amjad Masad shared about 'The Journey From No Laptop to a $3B Company' with the message that 'The value is not in the coding itself...' on Instagram, highlighting Replit's remarkable growth trajectory.
author: Amjad Masad

title: GLM-5: From Vibe Coding to Agentic Engineering
description: Simon Willison analyzed Z.ai's GLM-5 model release (754B parameters, 1.51TB), noting the industry's shift toward 'Agentic Engineering' as the professional term for what Andrej Karpathy and Addy Osmani have been discussing. Tested the model with OpenRouter generating a pelican on a bicycle.
author: Simon Willison

title: cysqlite—A New SQLite Driver in Cython
description: Simon Willison explored Charles Leifer's new cysqlite project, a ground-up Cython rewrite of pysqlite3. Used Claude Code to build a WebAssembly wheel (688KB) that can run in Pyodide, demonstrating advanced AI-assisted cross-compilation work. The biggest change involves transaction handling, with improved support for custom virtual tables.
author: Simon Willison

title: WSJ Interview: Replit CEO on AI Coding Boom and Vibe Coding
description: Amjad Masad, CEO of Replit, discussed the AI coding boom, the recent selloff of software stocks, and the rise of 'vibe coding' in a Wall Street Journal feature published February 11, 2026.
author: Amjad Masad

title: Introducing Showboat and Rodney for Agent Demos
description: Simon Willison released two new tools addressing a key challenge in working with coding agents: having them test what they've built AND demonstrate that software to overseers. Showboat and Rodney help create artifacts that show agent progress and capabilities, going beyond automated tests to provide visual demonstrations of agent-produced software.
author: Simon Willison

title: scBench: Evaluating AI Agents on Single-Cell RNA-seq Analysis
description: ArXiv paper 2602.09063 introducing a benchmark for LLM agents that write code, invoke tools, and iterate toward goals. Published 5 days ago, focuses on evaluating agent capabilities in bioinformatics workflows.
author: Research Team

title: Structured Context Engineering for File-Native Agentic Systems
description: Simon Willison reviewed a new paper by Damon McMillan exploring LLM context tasks with large SQL schemas (up to 10,000 tables) across 11 models and 4 formats. Key finding: frontier models (Opus 4.5, GPT-5.2, Gemini 2.5 Pro) benefited from filesystem-based context retrieval, but open source models had less convincing results. The 'grep tax' showed TOON format consumed 740% more tokens than YAML at scale due to model unfamiliarity.
author: Simon Willison

title: AI Doesn't Reduce Work—It Intensifies It
description: Simon Willison discussed HBR research from Berkeley Haas on AI's impact on work intensity. The study found AI introduced a new rhythm of managing multiple active threads simultaneously: manually writing code while AI generated alternatives, running parallel agents, or reviving deferred tasks. This created cognitive load and a sense of always juggling, even as work felt productive. Willison noted he frequently finds his mental energy depleted after just 1-2 hours despite getting 'so much done'.
author: Simon Willison

title: Vouch: A System for Managing AI-Generated PRs
description: Simon Willison covered Mitchell Hashimoto's new Vouch system to address the deluge of worthless AI-generated PRs in open source projects. The system allows projects to require vouching from contributors, with options to 'denounce' bad actors. Integration into GitHub is simple via published GitHub Actions. The system is generic and not tied to GitHub specifically.
author: Simon Willison

title: Claude Opus 4.6 Fast Mode: 2.5x Faster at 6x Price
description: Simon Willison detailed Anthropic's new 'fast mode' for Claude Opus 4.6, available via /fast in Claude Code. The mode offers 2.5x faster responses but at 6x the normal price ($30/million input, $150/million output vs $5/$25 standard). There's a 50% discount until February 16th. Opus 4.6 also offers up to 1,000,000 token context at 2x price once input exceeds 200,000 tokens.
author: Simon Willison

title: How StrongDM's AI Team Builds Software Without Looking at Code
description: Simon Willison featured StrongDM's AI team implementing 'Dark Factory' level AI adoption, where no human even looks at the code coding agents produce. This public description of their 'Software Factories' and 'Agentic Moment' approach represents one of the most extreme examples of autonomous AI software development publicly shared.
author: Simon Willison

title: AgentStepper: Interactive Debugging of Software Development Agents
description: ArXiv paper 2602.06593 introducing software development agents powered by LLMs for automating tasks like environment setup. Published 8 days ago, focuses on interactive debugging approaches for AI coding agents.
author: Research Team

title: Context-Aware Reasoning for Inter-Procedural Vulnerability Detection
description: ArXiv paper 2602.06751 describing LLM-based agents for vulnerability detection using mock-court approach. Published 8 days ago, demonstrates competitive performance with state-of-the-art SAST tools.
author: Research Team

title: Large Language Models in Software Documentation
description: ArXiv paper 2602.04938 providing a survey on LLM-based agents for software engineering, covering current challenges and future directions. Published 8 days ago.
author: Research Team

title: Running Pydantic's Monty Rust Sandboxed Python Subset in WebAssembly
description: Simon Willison got Pydantic's Monty (a custom Python-like language subset in Rust) working in WebAssembly, creating a sandbox-in-a-sandbox. The article explores the growing landscape of sandboxes for running untrusted code, with Monty available as both a Rust library and Python package.
author: Simon Willison

title: Heroku Transitions to Sustaining Engineering Model
description: Simon Willison reported on Heroku's transition to a 'sustaining engineering model' focused on stability, security, reliability, and support rather than new features. Salesforce (owner) is focusing investments on 'enterprise-grade AI' instead. Willison noted this is frustrating corporate communication and he needs to migrate his last project on Heroku (likely to Fly).
author: Simon Willison
